critique: This executive order focuses on improving the foster care system and promoting adoption, with an emphasis on finding permanent families for children, especially those who are older, in sibling groups, or have disabilities. It encourages partnerships between state agencies and faith-based organizations, aims to improve access to resources for caregivers and youth, and seeks to ensure equality of treatment for all families. The order also addresses the prevention of unnecessary removal of children and securing permanency. It does not directly address immigration, executive power, or federalism in a significant way. The order seems to promote social inclusion by focusing on the needs of diverse children and families. It also seems to promote some government intervention by increasing the amount of oversight and data collection performed by the federal government. The order does not seem to have a strong ideological tilt.
